reviewText:
When the LEGO series burst onto the scene with LEGO Star Wars in 2005, it was an instant hit. The game's simple controls, fun humor, and family-friendly gameplay made it a classic among players and assured it a spot in the upper echelon of licensed games. However, as the LEGO series started branching out and extending its trademark influence across other properties, it seemed as if some of the spark had faded. The LEGO Indiana Jones games in particular were criticized for having numerous glitches and having a general lack of polish.

When I started playing LEGO: Harry Potter, I had some serious concerns. However, it looks like Traveler's Tales has gotten back to doing what they do best with LEGO Harry Potter, and the love that they put into this title definitely shows.

Right from the moment you start the game, the affection the developers have for the series as a whole is apparent. The opening cutscene features a mish-mash of humorous takes on the opening scenes from Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone mixed with a few nods to both the fans of the books as well as previous LEGO games. I won't spoil anything here, but it must be said that the cutscenes in LEGO Harry Potter are definitely on par with the best of the cutscenes from the LEGO: Star Wars series.

The cutscenes definitely continue the series' trademark humor, and the gameplay follows suit by providing users with more of the same puzzle-platform style of gameplay that has been featured in previous LEGO titles. Although this sounds a little disparaging, it's actually quite a boon for the game in this instance. The LEGO fanbase is one that must have some repetitious elements, especially when you consider that many of the players are quite young. Having a repetitious format may become tiresome in a game series designed for adults, but with a franchise with fans with single-digit ages, being able to hop right in and know what to do is key for success.

That's not to say, however, that there are no new elements in LEGO Harry Potter. Instead of a single action you can take with items in game, LEGO Harry Potter features more than ten special spells that you can use to achieve various effects in the game. These spells can be easily cycled through using the shoulder button, and add a new puzzle element to the game.

Although there are quite a few spells (including the always-funny Ridikkulus spell), the one you are most likely to use in 90% of situations is Wingardium Leviosa. This levitation spell is the first spell you learn and will be used to move objects around and interact with switches. The Lumos spell is also used quite a bit, along with various graduated intervals of attack-style spells including Expecto Patronus and Incendio.

And speaking of combat, there is a fair bit of magic-based fighting in LEGO Harry Potter. This is a change of pace from previous LEGO games, but it sits nicely with the overall tone of the game. The Harry Potter series of movies and books has always been well-known for its magical creatures and (at least in the beginning) fantastical battle sequences. Although boss battles generally do contain some amount of puzzling, you will be able to fire off magical spells from your wand fairly easily to overpower your opponent.

LEGO Harry Potter does a great job of refreshing and updating the LEGO series for the Harry Potter universe, but unfortunately, there are several problems that remain. One of the problems that returns from other games is the camera. Though you may not notice it if you are playing co-op and staying close to your partner, if you are playing with an adventurous partner or with a bunch of AI-controlled characters, you'll notice the camera following the wrong character or zooming out to the point of near-unplayability.

Another thing that you must know coming in is that the best way to experience LEGO Harry Potter is with a friend. Playing by yourself can be quite an exercise in frustration, and AI-controlled characters can be painfully difficult to deal with, especially when you need to get them to a certain platform or area so you can proceed. Sure, you can always use your Wingardium Leviosa spell to get them in the correct position, but this can become quite the chore and make the game feel more like Hogwarts' babysitting service than a real adventure.

A final complaint I have with this title is with the game's hub system. While hubs in previous LEGO titles have been expansive with plenty to explore, the Diagon Alley hub feels almost overwhelming. I had to search for several minutes just to find the character-purchase shop, and it felt like a chore going through the different areas, waiting for loading screens, and then tracking down who I needed to get new wardrobe choices, extra spells, or watch cutscenes. Though this may sound like a small gripe, I really relished the overall simplicity of previous games, and the complicated nature of the hub world just took away from the game's overall immersion.

Technically speaking, everything in Harry Potter maintains the status quo, which is a good thing. Cutscenes look polished, and in-game graphics maintain the signature brick-style that has become synonymous with the LEGO series. The only quibble I have with the game's visual styling (and it is a minor one) is that environments can get a little too busy at times and it can be hard to be precise with your targeting when you have dozens of interactive elements on screen. However, this only occurs in a handful of areas, and can usually be remedied by walking up to whatever element you want to interact with and targeting it directly (instead of just heading in the general direction and pressing a button.

LEGO: Harry Potter Years 1-4 is certainly the best of the post-Star Wars LEGO games. The story material is handled wonderfully (though if you've never read the books or watched the movies, prepare to be lost), and the gameplay is a great mix of familiar devices and new elements. Although the inevitable follow-up to this title may take a darker turn, I look forward to experiencing it all the same.

This game brought back my childhood; and I can't decide which part I was more invested in as a kid. Harry Potter or LEGO? Or building Harry Potter with LEGO?
Doesn't matter though because the game combines both and that on PC.
Over ten years ago I started reading the Harry Potter books and I had been playing with LEGO already even before I could read. I used to beg my mother to take me to the movies to see HP and it was the one thing I was looking forward to the most all the years. I had folders at home with every little piece of information there was to collect in newspapers and magazines. I had posters all over the wall and watched the movies regularily. My friends and I even replayed some of the scenes in our garden. I went to the midnight release of HP6 in a bookstore when I was maybe 10 and there was a picture of me in the local town's newspaper since I actually dressed up.

I ♥♥♥♥ing cried after watching HP7.2 in the cinema because it felt as if I was losing part of myself (I was 15 be considerate). My childhood seemed to have reached its end with no more Harry Potter movies being in production.

And years later I found out about this game. For the love of god, I cannot properly describe my happiness.
Loosely keeping to the movies it still generates the general mood of the (earlier) ones. There are a lot of fun moments and it's even more enjoyable when you've got a friend over to play it with. It even includes the original soundtrack which just hits you right in your chest whenever a new piece starts.

For anyone having not yet played a LEGO game, you basically go through the chapters, sometimes being able to switch character, collecting LEGO money and shooting spells at everything you can point your wand at because, guess what, that gives you even more money. Later, when you replay a chapter, you can choose other people to play as who you unlock through the course of the game and who have different abilities and will let you enter new areas of the game.

If you like Harry Potter
or if you like LEGO
or even better
if you like both

reviewText: This Game Is BOMB! I Should Buy RIGHT NOW H.P Years 5-7
Well, it's a lego game, for people who have played them before that should be enough, it's a good, addicting game, but with a lot of bugs. I'm still playing trying to get 100%.

LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1 - 4

What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's got that same LEGO charm and goofiness that we've all come to know and love since 2005's LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game. Parodying the first four Harry Potter movies (The Philosopher's Stone, The Chamber of Secrets, The Prisoner of Azkaban, and The Goblet of Fire), this game has the potential to bring new people into the Harry Potter fandom. It inspired me to watch the eight movies, and I must say that they're all wonderful. The puzzles in this game are clever, the satirical humor is an amazing thing to have considering how dark the movies get, and the idea of having the 'Dexter's Diner' and level select rooms as the Diagon Alley and Hogwarts Castle (respectively) overworlds are truly fantastic.

But, I'm afraid I can't give this game a perfect score like I would for other titles in the series. LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1 - 4 falls just short due to one fatal flaw in the game: Game breaking glitches.

In Year 3 Act 6, right near the beginning of the level, there are two switches that you need to hit to melt ice off a door to continue on. Hitting either of these crashes the game. But there is a workaround to it, thankfully. Just go into 2 player mode, place player 1 in a corner far away from a door, have player two hit the right switch, and have them drop out back to player 1. After waiting for a few minutes, do this again, but this time have player 2 take blind shots at the left switch, and then wait after you hit it. I know, it's convoluted and crazy, but it works. In the same level, there's a glass window that you need to break. The first time I tried to break it, the sound played but the entity in the map remained. This is fixed by a simple re-entering of the level, or restarting the game if you want to be sure. Just remember the glitch before that window.

But in Year 4 Act 2....there's a huge problem. The third dragon you take care of, a blue one, is supposed to be raised up on a platform whenever you walk onto a certain spot on the walkway on his cage. Instead of working like he should, he instead falls right through the platform. As this is a glitch in the physics engine for the game, I kept trying again but had the same result. But one time the dragon went through the ceiling of his cage. And another time, he worked. BUT, the fireball that he shoots teleported as soon as it left his mouth, and hit the back left corner of the platform. I had heard that you, again, needed to go into two player mode to get this to work. The first time it almost did, but then he went through the ceiling again. Which is, admittedly, kinda funny. But the other two tries just had the same result as the first time I encountered this glitch. As of yet, I have not found a workaround or fix in the files to remedy this problem.

Overall, I give this game an 8/10, and highly recommend it to any fan of Harry Potter, or the LEGO games in general. But, for the time being, I would also recommend that you get it in physical form just in case the above glitches are Steam exclusive. I will edit my score later on should there ever be a patch released for this game that fixes the above glitches.

reviewText:
This is a fun game for anyone who liked Harry Potter and is familiar with the story/movies. Yes, there are some technical issues sometimes (game minimizing itself is one of mine), but I've never found them to be so invasive that I couldn't enjoy the game. The graphics are actually quite nice, the levels are big and there's lots to explore, and the characters are fun. I love the dialogue-free thing (who REALLY likes sitting there for five minutes listening to dialogue when you've already read the subtitles?) and the fact that there are little jokes put in from time to time that provide some nice comic relief.

This game tends to keep you in a good mood because of its humour and the fact that it isn't extremely difficult. As far as I can tell, it is very, very hard to die in this game (at least in the first few levels--I can't speak for the later ones as I haven't played them yet), so that provides some relief for gamers who are reaching the end of their patience after getting killed dozens of times on the same level of their favourite more difficult games. You also seem to get a lot of reward for a little effort. Run around hitting things with spells left and right and you're amply rewarded with coins. In these ways, LEGO Harry Potter is definitely a kids' game but not so much that an adult who loves Harry Potter can't enjoy it, especially an adult who doesn't always want to be stuck playing the typical violent, bloody FPS all the time.

I can also see how this would be fun to play with a friend if you have a controller or two. The multiplayer option is always there--you don't have to play any special mode to enjoy co-op play--so your friend can jump in to help you out (or make things more difficult, depending on the friend) anytime.

All in all, I would definitely recommend LEGO Harry Potter to anyone who likes the series. It's purely a fun, enjoyable game with nice little jokes thrown in. It'll make you smile and give you hours of fun for not too much money.

The gameplay is fantastic; it is a LEGO game after all.  The game has puzzles, some moderate action and is overall quite enjoyable.  The puzzles aren't anything too mind blowing, they're pretty standard for anyone who's played a LEGO game: Smash a couple things here, use a special ability there.  However, the controls do not support the mouse and will reset to defaults upon restarting the game, so I would highly reccomend the use of a gamepad; it makes life easier.

As far as graphics go the game is quite well optimized and looks pretty great; the screenshots on the store page do it absolutely no good.  With my current PC, (R9-280, 8GB of RAM and an FX-6300) I am getting a framerate of around 350 frames per second with all settings maxed at 1080p.  The game seems to compensate for its mediocre shading and texturing with some decent depth of field, bloom, and motion blur.  Some may argue that those effects are simply put in place to cover up bad graphics, however that's exactly what they do; The post processing effects cover up mediocre graphics, which is fine in my book.  The game looks great, and provides incredible performance.

Fun?  Absolutely.  It's a LEGO game for christ's sake!  There is little more fun than running around smashing everything in sight and flinging spells aimlessly around Hogwarts.  The perfect game for any Harry Potter fan who is a child at heart.

Aspect        Score                Gameplay        7.5                Graphics        8                Fun        9.5
Overall Score: 8.3

Warning:  go into your Windows playback device settings and change the default format to 24 bit @ 48000 Hz, the game will crash on startup otherwise.

I've played two lego games so far: LOTR and HP. I must say LOTR is awesome action pack and I love it whereas HP in my opinion was boring BS. I gave Harry Potter 90minutes and as a fan of the series I really tried to like the game. I played it with xbox360 controller it's one of the rare games where keyboard is actually worse, mainly because mouse has no function. So everyone playing lego games controller is THAT much bettter.

The first 90 minutes made me first of all hate the coin collecting. First I thought you need to collect them to be able to buy stuff. I still don't know if you can buy stuff, but I hate destroying everything and collecting the coin explosions. Tbh I think there is no actual benefit for it other than 100% completion.

I was able to learn the first levitation spell at my first magic class and the spell system is not my cup of tee. I think holding X and aiming a crosshair at some torches and bookshelves and whatnot is kinda lame. The character switching is stupid when the inactive character always runs back to harry potter (who is rarely playable and useless character mostly during my 90 minutes in). The extra characters would be fun I guess with friends to co-op, but they really should follow you around rather than returning to room/area entrance which in some cases is very far away.

The puzzles were pretty boring especially levitating bits and pieces and most of all Scabbers puzzles were lame. Students in peril... LAME. I didn't get into any real action except for pulling chains and opening locks... and collect more coins. I would also like to have character names visible since these lego guys aren't always that recognizable. That was more of a problem in LOTR with the four hobbits, but also a negative in HP.

I bet it gets more interesting after more hours, but for me this game did not deliver. And I may compare too much to LEGO Lord of the rings that delivered instantly and was action packed action game with real voice actors. Potter characters speak gipperish and made it childish and ruined the fun for me. Even the LEGO jokes felt awkward with Harry Potter mumbling. The jokes do work in LOTR when there is real voice acting and the atmosphere in cinematics is fantastic.

On a scale 0-5 I would give harry potter 1.5 and LOTR would get 4.

I've downloaded a 100% save (couldn't find 20% that I needed), but the game is not the same, nothing to explore, can't enjoy with that anymore.

reviewText:
Bought this game to play it with my younger sister, expected a good co-op platformer with some action and puzzles thrown in the mix, above all , I expected a fun, well thought out package.

This game is really far from fun, it seems that cuting development costs was their number one priority. The gameplay mechanics are so offensively simple that I don't see anybody enjoying themselves while playing it. And don't be mistaken, it's not like they simplified the game in some areas in order to appeal to the younger audience, no. They simply designed this piece of ♥♥♥♥ without any depth what so ever, none. It's just so plain and so unintuitive in everything it does. It became so basic in the ways it approaches things that there's no enjoyment to be had once you actually manage to complete a level. Flying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ broomstick doesn't feel any different to walking.

There's no point in using your brain at all while playing this game, in the end you'll still be forced to just run around for a minute or two, smashing everything around you in order to get enough scrap to build the thing that can help you proceed to the next room. There's nothing smart about it, nothing clever. In their efforts to secure the highest profit margin possible they produced an experience without any substance, just a long, tiring series of corridors, fetch quests and weak - ♥♥♥ HP references.

If you're looking for a engaging expereince to enjoy with your youngsters, please, PLEASE, look further, avoid this game at all costs, even if you are a fan of the HP universe.

Harry Potter in LEGO, what could you possible not like about this combination? In this game, you'll play through years 1 to 4 at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry during the time of the rise of Lord Voldemort. This was a huge undertaking by the development team given the excitement and anticipation for the game, and unfortunately I don't have many good things to say about the first installment.

You'll find yourself battling from Dudley's house, through the secret canals and dungeons of Hogwarts and all the way into the forbidden forrest. And for what you might ask? Simply to graduate from school, but it wasn't that hard when I went!

I genuinely feel that this game would be better suited to hardcore fans of the franchise, and I also genuinely feel that the development team didn't take this game seriously enough. The games mechanics are much like all the other LEGO games, and it is a successful business model so there's no arguments there. It does however lack unique mechanics, engrossment and immersion. Overall it does feel too much like too much of a kids game for kids.

With all of this said, I would still recomend it. It's charming, mindless, nothing unique and short-lived. If you're a huge fan of the franchise it's definitely worth the time. I wouldn't recommend it so much for those who aren't huge Harry Potter fans. So given you understand all of this, you're able to make your own judgements.

I played this game for the first time in 2010 on the Nintendo Wii, and I saw this on sale for £2.49, so I bought it for PC seeing as I sold my Wii.

STORY:

The game goes through Harry Potter's first four years at Hogwarts (Philosopher's Stone/Sorcerer's Stone, Chamber of Secrets, Prisoner of Azkaban and Goblet of Fire). There are 6 levels in each year, along with some mucking about around the Hogwarts free-roam. Unfortunately, each story feels shorter than the last, seeing as there is a big difference between the amount of play in Year 1 and the amount of play in Year 4. Also, Goblet of Fire doesn't really feel like it fits in, seeing as it's about 2 hours of gameplay right at the end.

GAMEPLAY:

As you go on your journey, you'll unlock a full range of spells:

Expelliarmus

Riddikulus

Expecto Patronum

Lumos/Lumos Solem

Wingardium Leviosa

Immobulus

Reducto

Plus the ability to summon a pet, turn into an Animagus or use a magical item.

The levels can be quite short, and you generally just use the spells to solve puzzles and, often in Year 4, defeat enemies.

GRAPHICS

The graphics are OK, but Years 5-7 has the upper hand.

FREE ROAM

You can explore all areas of Hogwarts Castle eventually (you unlock most of the areas in Year 1, a few in Year 2, a few in Year 3 and a few in Year 4. Plenty of stuff to keep you busy, like saving Students in Peril and hunting for new characters.

CONCLUSION

I may have said some bad points of this game, but it's still a nice little package of Harry Potter magic.

I played this game for the first time in 2010 on the Nintendo Wii, and I saw this on sale for £2.49, so I bought it for PC seeing as I sold my Wii.

STORY:

The game goes through Harry Potter's first four years at Hogwarts (Philosopher's Stone/Sorcerer's Stone, Chamber of Secrets, Prisoner of Azkaban and Goblet of Fire). There are 6 levels in each year, along with some mucking about around the Hogwarts free-roam. Unfortunately, each story feels shorter than the last, seeing as there is a big difference between the amount of play in Year 1 and the amount of play in Year 4. Also, Goblet of Fire doesn't really feel like it fits in, seeing as it's about 2 hours of gameplay right at the end.

GAMEPLAY:

As you go on your journey, you'll unlock a full range of spells:

Expelliarmus

Riddikulus

Expecto Patronum

Lumos/Lumos Solem

Wingardium Leviosa

Immobulus

Reducto

Plus the ability to summon a pet, turn into an Animagus or use a magical item.

The levels can be quite short, and you generally just use the spells to solve puzzles and, often in Year 4, defeat enemies.

GRAPHICS

The graphics are OK, but Years 5-7 has the upper hand.

FREE ROAM

You can explore all areas of Hogwarts Castle eventually (you unlock most of the areas in Year 1, a few in Year 2, a few in Year 3 and a few in Year 4. Plenty of stuff to keep you busy, like saving Students in Peril and hunting for new characters.

CONCLUSION

I may have said some bad points of this game, but it's still a nice little package of Harry Potter magic.

It's a LEGO game so you destroy the environment to rebuild whatever you need to progress.
On the first run-through it's a bit irritating to see all the stuff that you cannot use yet. If you aim for completeness you basically have to re-run levels. Besides the levels and connecting them is Hogwarts castle. You often have to progress in one to progress in the other. Finding important stuff gets easier as you discover the hidden detectors and paying for them gets easier with the equally hidden score multiplier - score translating directly to money.
The controls are pretty tight apart from the occasional unintentional spell marker and the rare jumping towards or away from the camera - nothing rage-worthy. The camera follows you around the levels sort of on rails and can be nudged a little bit in each direction.
Since the game is a bit older there is no voice acting but you're still well-directed and if you know Harry Potter than you likely have a good idea what's about to happen.
I generally dislike when games employ vanishing rewards - here the coins dropping from destruction vanish in seconds. I understand that games don't want to track every coin in all the levels but at least give me time to finish the scene.
Besides the timed vanishing, coins are sometimes simply dropped behind a wall or into the abyss and thus unavailable to the (early) player.
